page.title: 01KIRKCUDBRIGHT BAY
page.content: It is here that the River Dee meets the open sea. The land on either side of the bay is wild and wind-swept and for the most part surrounded by precipitous cliffs. The Ross headland is very hilly and used mainly for cattle and sheep farming. Save that which connects several farms on the way to the Ross Bay, there are no roads, only tracks. Opposite is the Little Ross Island, with its lighthouse, now operated automatically. Across the bay lies Torrs farm, famous for its champion Clydesdale horses. Most of the land on this side however, is owned by the Ministry of Defence as a misile-testing range and is therefore inaccessable to the public. It consists of grassland and small wooded areas. The coast prior to the Range is a favourite haunt of anglers.
